Angel, Zan, and the secrets of the lost, Part 12.
Monster Rancher Metropolis: Library: Fan Fiction, Poetry, Birthday List, Links & Non-Fiction Archive: Completed Epics Section III: Angel, Zan, and the secrets of the lost, Part 12.
By Daeore Dermegil on Saturday, March 22, 2003 - 05:47 am:

Hey everyone! Sorry about the long wait... Life seems to have well... become some thing I have to pay more attention to. SO, I dont have as much time as I once did to sort my thoughts out and write stuff. Anyhow, Enjoy.

***

That night, after a small celebration of our victory, we were allowed again to stay in the village. Durahan, after a long soak in a small hot spring, seemed to be only bruised by the battle. After getting cleaned up, his steps were sure again, if a little weary. But despite his obvious lack of energy, he still denied that he was tired. Sarah's ankle was also only a minor hurt, and caused her only a slight limp after she too took a bath in the hot spring near town. All in all, we did well for our very first 'serious' fight. But one thing worried me.

Angel. She had not suffered any physical harm. But I could see... Pain, a torment of the soul. Some thing was bothering her in a way most humans never experience. She looked away from me when I looked at her with the question on the tip of my tongue. Sarah, too, couldn't get any answers either.

Some thing was wrong. This entire situation stunk of something, and Angel knew what it was. I could feel it. But, I wouldn't get an answer from her. So, I looked elsewhere for the answer. I looked in the book. Some how, I felt the answer was in there, between the hard covers of that old tome.

I was right, and as I read, I could feel my own soul cry out for Angel. My own pain seemed like a spark against an inferno. I found, after the pages containing the near end of the ancient's civilization, where the Shrine Keepers had become monster hunters. Experimenting with humans, in a desperate attempt to regain ground lost to the monster armies, some hunters had undergone a monster merging. Instead of the two pedestals, a third was added. Two monsters, and a human, merged into a single form. Again I saw the madness that war brings. Sealing the monsters in disks was good. Having to hunt down rouge monsters... Not really pleasant, but even in this age, it had to be done on occasion.

But this? Madness! Creating something that could just as easily fail, and cause more damage. We had already seen what just one of these... Hybrids, could do. My mind boggled at the thought of a small army of them. Reading further, past a detailed example of the process of how the merging was done, it confirmed my thoughts on the matter. Yes, the process wasn't always successful. Some times, a man-monster would go die before even taking a step off the pedestal, or even, as with the Dean, go insane, the difference in mentality distorting the person's mind.

Some of these experiments had worked, with great success. People gaining a Pixie's magic, or dragon wings, or a golem's great strength. But it was still, not enough. There was more too. The experiments were continued, in a frantic effort to save what was left of their civilization. But, that is where the book ended. The last words, reading as such, "Despite the mediocre results of the man-monster experiments, positive data was obtained. There is a possibility of creating a monster, artificial like the Hengar, but still organic. Our only hope is that this effort works, and soon, as they're few places left that have not fallen to the monster armies."

That was it. Answers, leading to questions, with only one certainty. What ever it was the ancients had in mind as this 'last resort', it had failed. The evidence was all over the world, right?

I closed the book, looking over to the nearly burned out candle. Durahan was resting, sitting in the way of the door. Sarah was in the single bedroom in the cabin the villagers provided for us after the celebration. And Angel... When I looked away from the candle, was standing quietly beside the desk, just outside of the candle's small glow. I could see tears in her eyes.

'You know.' I said to her, not asked.

She nodded, looking away from me. 'You know, and you are ashamed... Why?' She wouldn't answer me. I knew she wouldn't, but the question seemed to burn in my mind the longer I held it in. 'Some thing my father discovered along with you, makes you ashamed. What? What is this secret? What secret could be so dark that...'

A sudden vision from the cave, the morning after Angel and I fled from the ranch, the angry shout that died on my lips... But not this time... Tears filled my eyes as well.

'What secret is so dark that my father had to die to keep you safe from it?!?!' I yelled at her through my own tears. 'What secret could make you cry...?'

Angel was holding me then, I could feel her arms wrapped around me, comforting me as my mother had when things troubled me. I wanted to push her away until I had an answer from her, to get some sort of... Clue to this whole mess. But I couldn't ask. The anger I felt, so sharply pointed at Angel, slid away, shattering like a glass window and vanishing like puff of smoke.

After finding my voice again, the tears burned out of me again, I remember speaking before I fell asleep, 'I will uncover this secret. My father's last wish, your sorrow, and my vengeance, I will find out what this is all about.'

***

Again, I pause my writing. The morning sun becoming painful in its mid dawn brilliance, shining through the window of the small cabin we all rested in. I could feel the chewy brown root lose its potency, my eyes starting to blur as weariness crept up on me. Still more to write, but by the gods I was sleepy.

Lightly blowing on the freshly inked page, I shook out my hand. I could hear a faint wind blowing outside, the slight sigh of its passing almost like a lullaby in my current state.

I will write more tomorrow... Yes, after some rest...

By torey luvullo on Sunday, March 23, 2003 - 09:17 am:

here is a long answer that will not help, but hopefully will give you something to think about.

a lot of my time is spent on monster rancher, and tecmo, boards. what i see too often is fans taking ownership interest in the sequel to the game - in what is to come - and then becoming angry and turning aside from the game they enjoyed, because their suggestions do not become reality. yet they became fans of the game - ardent enough fans to become regulars on forums associated with that game - precisely because the game contained a spark of inspiration and ingenuity that reached them and touched them and caused them to celebrate the creativity involved with the original game's creation.

i am now a fan of your story. the last thing that i want to do is take an ownership interest in it, only to become disappointed when it goes in another direction. however you want to spin out the tale - even if you tally up the votes of others and proceed accordingly - is fine with me. you, the storyteller, have earned my faith in your storytelling.

as you can already tell, i abstain.
